cards.title: 'We've all met a Margo' / Penelope Keith's comic triumph on The Good Life
cards.rawTitle: Penelope Keith's comic triumph on The Good Life

item.title: 'We've all met a Margo': Penelope Keith's comic triumph on The Good Life
item.trailText: She’s a snob, a bully, a social climber and no doubt would be delighted by the emergence of Ukip. So why do we love Margo Leadbetter?
item.standFirst: She’s a snob, a bully, a social climber and no doubt would be delighted by the emergence of Ukip. So why do we love Margo Leadbetter?
item.body:
Who can forget Penelope Keith as Margo Leadbetter, wearing a tangerine kaftan, vigorously plumping the cushions of her three-piece suite on The Good Life? Or Margo, hysterical with nerves, cursing Miss Mountshaft before playing Maria in the amateur dramatic society’s production of The Sound of Music? Or Margo, wading through a sea of mud in yellow oilskins picking one runner bean at a time?

If you think about Margo on paper, it’s not pretty. She’s a snob, a bully and a social climber. She’s a Daily Mail reader, and no doubt would be delighted by the emergence of Ukip. She’s imperious. She’s rude. Why do we love her?

We’ve all met a Margo. There’s a teeny bit of Margo in all of us. Sometimes we really care what other people think. We desperately try to make the right impression. Of course, when we do this, it inevitably leads to us making completely the wrong impression.

I admit it. I identify with Margo. I have rather a posh voice. I am tall for a lady person. I can look imperious (not intentionally I hasten to add). In fact, one of my nicknames at school was Margo.

I warm to Margo because of her vulnerability. She may be a peacock, a princess and a fusspot but, deep down, I find her rather touching. Beneath the brittle, rather too cultivated exterior, she lacks confidence. Her clothes, her lady-of-the-manor persona and fantastic bossiness are all armour to help her navigate the battlefield of Surbiton.

The physical comedy is triumphant. Keith is statuesque, elegant and authoritative. Her distinct physicality is integral to Margo. So it’s all the more funny when Margo sits on a vibrating chair or falls over in the mud. Her pride has a long way to fall. For me, the best comedy mixes pathos with laugh-out-loud gags. Penelope Keith is so good at this. Her nuanced portrayal of Margo’s triumphs and humiliations means that she is a rounded and sympathetic character when she so easily could have been a one-dimensional surburban harridan.

I strive for this sort of quality in my comedy characters. I confess, I’ve produced plenty of unrounded characters who can exist successfully for only one, maybe two sketches. But, every so often, I find a goody – a Margo – who can run and run and never get boring.

A couple of years ago I went to a birthday party. The theme was The Good Life. We all know that Barbara is adorable, pert and doe eyed. Felicity Kendal became a massive sex symbol due to The Good Life. However, at the party, there were surprisingly few Barbaras. But there were at least 30 Margos. Magnificent and hilarious in equal measure.

  • Charlotte McDougall is performing at Underbelly Cowgate throughout the Edinburgh fringe as Gay Furnish: Flirt Coach

cards.title: Star Wars spin-off / Darth Vader set to return

item.title: Darth Vader set to return in Star Wars: Rogue One
item.trailText: Evil Sith lord rumoured to reappear in Gareth Edwards’ film, which centres on a group of rebels vying to steal plans to the first Death Star
item.standFirst: Evil Sith lord rumoured to reappear in Gareth Edwards’ film, which centres on a group of rebels vying to steal plans to the first Death Star
item.body:
Darth Vader will return in the Star Wars spin-off movie Rogue One, according to Birth.Movies.Death.

The fan site’s Devin Faraci, formerly of the generally reliable Badass Digest, reports the long-running space saga’s most iconic villain will have a string-pulling background role in Gareth Edwards’ film. He will appear on screen, possibly remotely via “viewscreen or holoprojection”, but will not be the main antagonist of the piece.

Rogue One is set in the period before the first Star Wars movie, first released in 1977, and is a heist movie centred on a group of rebels vying to steal the plans to the first Death Star. Vader’s presence somewhere in the frame therefore makes sense, as the Sith Lord would have been one of the nascent evil Empire’s main commanders during the period.

Related: Forest Whitaker in talks to join Star Wars: Rogue One

Also expected to appear would be Grand Moff Tarkin, commander of the first Death Star who was played memorably by Peter Cushing in Star Wars. Birth.Movies.Death. reports its source was unable to confirm whether the character would return.

__VIDEO_EMBED_gu-video-452769477__

If Vader does appear on screen for the first time since a brief turn in 2005’s Star Wars prequel Revenge of the Sith, he could be voiced once again by the veteran US actor James Earl Jones, who provided the villain’s velvety tones in the original trilogy (British actor Dave Prowse famously portrayed Vader on screen). Jones, 84, recently provided the voice for Vader in Disney’s Star Wars Rebels animated series. However, Oscar-winner Forest Whitaker was last month reported to be taking an unspecified role in Rogue One, and would make a fine replacement.

Related: Han Solo origins: Star Wars spin-off to be directed by Lego Movie team

Rogue One stars The Theory of Everything’s Felicity Jones, Riz Ahmed, Diego Luna and Ben Mendehlson. The title of the spin-off – Disney-owned Lucasfilm is referring to the film as its first “Star Wars Anthology” movie – suggests the rebels involved may be X-Wing pilots. Edwards’ film is due to hit cinemas on 16 December, 2016, approximately a year after JJ Abrams’ The Force Awakens kicks off a new trilogy of Star Wars movies.

cards.title: Jurassic World / Director criticises trailer for revealing too much of film
cards.rawTitle: Director criticises trailer for revealing too much of film

item.title: Jurassic World director criticises trailer for revealing too much of film
item.trailText: Following his criticism of a ‘sexist’ promotional clip, Colin Trevorrow says trailer was ‘challenging for an audience’
item.standFirst: Following his criticism of a ‘sexist’ promotional clip, Colin Trevorrow says trailer was ‘challenging for an audience’
item.body:
First, it was Jurassic World director Colin Trevorrow openly questioning the release of a “sexist” clip to promote his film. Then it was Terminator Genisys director Alan Taylor criticising the trailer campaign for revealing too much of the film’s plot. Now Trevorrow has had another pop at the Jurassic World marketing team, saying “they have shown far more of this movie than I would ever have wanted” in the film’s trailer.

Related: Jurassic World director backs Joss Whedon's criticism of "sexist" clip

In an interview with IGN, Trevorrow referred to a shot in the Jurassic World trailer that showed Chris Pratt riding his motorcycle among a flock of velociraptors, a bonding-type image at odds with the original films’ positioning of raptors as vicious predators – one that seemed to baffle potential audiences. Calling it “bananas”, Trevorrow added: “Your suspension of disbelief has to be earned. We’ve been earning it [in the movie], by the time that happens, for an hour and a half ... Every movie has its own logic, and if you’re introducing a new set of rules, to just show people snippets of something without them understanding the set of rules that define the movie, can be challenging for an audience.”

Trevorrow also appeared to criticise the expectations the trailer may raise as to the nature of Jurassic World, even as he agreed it would be successful in its purpose. He said: “This kind of marketing has historically been able to get a lot of people into theatres; I trust a lot of people will be calling their friends and saying: ‘It’s not like [the trailer] at all, it feels much more like Jurassic Park than we thought it would.’”

cards.title: Broadway theater-goer jumps on stage to charge phone – in fake outlet
cards.rawTitle: Broadway theater-goer jumps on stage to charge phone – in fake outlet

item.title: Broadway theater-goer jumps on stage to charge phone – in fake outlet
item.trailText: Audience member recounts how man jumped on stage before performance of Hand to God in New York hoping to charge his phone
item.standFirst: Audience member recounts how man jumped on stage before performance of Hand to God in New York hoping to charge his phone
item.body:
Theater etiquette rules are fairly straightforward: don’t be late, keep quiet during the show and if you are not a cast or crew member, stay off the stage.

These rules didn’t seem to trouble one audience member at Thursday’s performance of Hand to God, who startled crew and fellow theater-goers by climbing on to the stage of the Booth Theatre before the show started.

Once on stage, he tried to plug a cellphone charger into a power point on the show’s set which, it turns out, was fake.

Chris York, who was sitting in the mezzanine section on 2 July, recounted what happened on his Facebook page, and news of the audience member’s behavior was getting wider attention on Tuesday.

York told the Guardian the incident occurred about two minutes before the show was set to begin, and that the man who jumped to the stage was in his early 20s.

There were no stairs to the stage, York said, so to get to it the man had to leap and then walk about 15 feet to the outlet that, York said, was “clearly fake”.

“The whole time it was very bizarre,” York said.

At first, people thought it was a part of the show, he said, but once they realized the truth, the audience started laughing and heckling the man. The crew stopped the pre-show music, removed the charger and made an announcement to the audience prohibiting them from charging their phones on stage.

York said he couldn’t tell if the man said anything in response, but that the actors “were very aware of what happened”.

Hand to God actor Sarah Stiles questioned whether the audience member was reacting to a full moon or if he was just an idiot:

Actor Marc Kudisch informed audiences that set outlets are not the same as real outlets.

cards.title: Life imitating Up / 120 balloons, one man and a garden chair take to the skies
cards.rawTitle: 120 balloons, one man and a garden chair take to the skies

item.title: Life imitating Up: 120 balloons, one man and a garden chair take to the skies
item.trailText: Intrepid aviator Danny Boria explains why he spent 20mins soaring in the ‘funniest aircraft we could make’ before bailing out and being brought down to earth by the police
item.standFirst: Intrepid aviator Danny Boria explains why he spent 20mins soaring in the ‘funniest aircraft we could make’ before bailing out and being brought down to earth by the police
item.body:
For centuries, man has explored new ways to fly. On Sunday, Danny Boria, of Calgary, Canada, came up with a precise and domestically available answer: 120 party balloons, each 6ft in circumference, filled with helium and tied to a garden chair. “It was the funniest aircraft we could make,” he says. He flew freely for 20 to 30 minutes. Is it really so easy to fly? Sticking with the domestic theme, could you send even a shed or summerhouse into the sky?

“If you’ve got sufficient helium, you can lift anything,” says Kevin Garry, professor of experimental aerodynamics at Cranfield University. This sounds straightforward. A bit like the film Up. Large party balloons are easy to source. So is helium, if you can afford it (Boria spent $12,000 on a pallet and a half). But how do you know how many balloons you need? “There are buoyancy equations,” says Garry. It’s a matter of applying helium’s lifting power – roughly a gram per litre – to your own weight.

That’s what Boria did. He tested the load-bearing capacity of a single balloon with “a bunch of little weights”. Each balloon could carry 3-4lb. Next he calculated the number required for his own bodyweight (195lb), his parachute and the chair. “And then I added a couple hundred pounds”, as a precaution. He also talked to “experts on wind. We figured if we did it right, if we got enough helium and enough balloons, there’s no way it won’t work.”

Some have suggested Danny Deckchair was Boria’s inspiration, a film in which Rhys Ifans floats off to find true love. But Boria was not looking for love. He was looking to advertise his cleaning company, All Clean Natural, which makes chemical-free products. He spent $30,000 on the stunt but the company has taken “upwards of 15,000 orders” since Sunday, he says. “We didn’t lose sight of the whole vision. We kept solving problems, and the idea just kept getting better. In business, you really need to follow your effort.”

Initially, Boria planned to jump out of an aeroplane, with an All Clean Natural logo on his parachute. “We tried everyone,” he says. But no local pilot was prepared to risk their licence. His balloon idea seems novel, but it has precursors. In 2008, Kent Couch, from Oregon, travelled 200 miles in a balloon-and-deckchair combo. Before that, there was Roald Dahl’s The Twits, written in 1979, in which Mr Twit ties balloons to Mrs Twit’s arms. Boria said he heard popping sounds during his journey and eventually bailed out of his chair using his parachute. He had learned to skydive especially, but there was no dummy run – “It was too expensive.”

In addition to balloons bursting, there was one further flight hazard. Boria spent Sunday night in jail. He has been charged with “mischief” - other charges are pending - for leaving an unpiloted garden chair flying around. It came down 50km south, in High River Alberta.
